module0.title: Getting Started
module0.description: Introduction to C programming, setup, and basic concepts

setup.title: Environment Setup & Hello World
setup.description: Learn how to set up your C development environment and write your first program

content.text: C is a general-purpose programming language developed by Dennis Ritchie at Bell Labs in the early 1970s. It is known for its efficiency, flexibility, and close-to-hardware programming capabilities. C is widely used for system programming, embedded systems, and application development.

To write and run C programs, you need a text editor and a compiler. Popular options include GCC (GNU Compiler Collection), Clang, and IDEs like Code::Blocks, Dev-C++, or Visual Studio Code with C extensions.

Let's break down the Hello World program:
1. #include <stdio.h> - Includes the standard input/output library
2. int main() - Entry point of the program
3. printf() - Function to print text to the console
4. return 0 - Indicates successful program execution

compilation.title: Compilation Process
compilation.description: Understanding how C code is transformed into executable programs

content.text: The preprocessor handles directives that begin with #. It includes header files, expands macros, and performs conditional compilation.
The compiler translates the preprocessed C code into assembly language, then into object code (machine code in binary format).
The linker combines object files and library functions to create the final executable program.

questions.question: Who developed the C programming language?
What is the purpose of the #include directive?
What does the main() function represent in a C program?
options: The entry point of the program

project.title: Interactive Hello World
project.description: Create a program that asks for the user's name and greets them personally
hints: Use scanf() to read input from the user
Use a character array to store the name

module1.title: Basics of C Programming
module1.description: Learn variables, data types, operators, and basic I/O operations

variables.title: Variables and Data Types
variables.description: Understanding how to declare and use variables in C

content.text:
C provides several basic data types to store different kinds of values:
- int: for integers (whole numbers)
- float: for single-precision floating-point numbers
- double: for double-precision floating-point numbers
- char: for single characters
Variables must be declared before use. They can be declared and initialized separately or together.
Constants are fixed values that cannot be changed during program execution. They can be defined using #define or const keyword.

operators.title: Operators in C
operators.description: Learn about arithmetic, relational, logical, and other operators

content.text: C provides basic arithmetic operators for mathematical operations: +, -, *, /, % (modulus).
Relational operators compare values and return 1 (true) or 0 (false). Logical operators combine boolean expressions.
Assignment operators assign values to variables. Increment/decrement operators increase or decrease values by 1.

io.title: Input and Output
io.description: Learn how to read input from users and display output

content.text: printf() is used to display formatted output. Format specifiers like %d, %f, %c are used for different data types.
scanf() is used to read formatted input from the user. It's important to use the correct format specifiers.
Format specifiers control how data is displayed. Escape sequences are used for special characters.

questions.question: Which data type is used to store a single character?
What is the output of: int x = 5; printf("%d", x++);
Which format specifier is used for float values in printf()?
Which operator is used for logical AND?

project.title: Basic Calculator
project.description: Create a calculator that performs basic arithmetic operations
hints: Use a switch statement to handle different operators
Use %lf format specifier for double values

module5.title: Pointers and Memory Management
module5.description: Master pointers, dynamic memory allocation, and memory layout

pointers.title: Pointer Fundamentals
pointers.description: Understanding what pointers are and how to use them effectively

content.text: A pointer is a variable that stores the memory address of another variable. Pointers are powerful but can be tricky to understand. They allow direct memory manipulation and are essential for advanced C programming.
Pointers can be incremented, decremented, and used in arithmetic operations. The increment/decrement depends on the size of the data type the pointer points to.
Arrays and pointers are closely related in C. The name of an array acts as a pointer to its first element. Array elements can be accessed using both array notation and pointer arithmetic.

memory.title: Dynamic Memory Allocation
memory.description: Learn how to allocate and deallocate memory at runtime

content.text: malloc() allocates a block of memory of specified size and returns a pointer to the beginning of the block. free() deallocates the memory previously allocated by malloc().
calloc() allocates memory and initializes all bits to zero. realloc() changes the size of previously allocated memory block.
Common memory-related errors include memory leaks, dangling pointers, and buffer overflows. Proper memory management is crucial for robust programs.

layout.title: Memory Layout
layout.description: Understanding how memory is organized in a C program

content.text:
A C program's memory is divided into several segments:
1. Text segment: Stores executable code
2. Data segment: Stores global and static variables
3. Heap: Dynamic memory allocation
4. Stack: Function calls and local variables

Stack memory is automatically managed and fast, but limited in size. Heap memory is larger but requires manual management. Stack variables are automatically destroyed when they go out of scope, while heap memory must be explicitly freed.

questions.question: What does the * operator do with a pointer?
Which function is used to allocate memory dynamically?
What is the purpose of the free() function?
What happens when you increment a pointer?
options: Adds size of data type to the address

questions.question: Which memory segment stores global variables?

project.title: Dynamic Array Manager
project.description: Create a program that manages a dynamic array with add, remove, and resize operations
hints: Use a struct to represent the dynamic array with data pointer, size, and capacity
Implement functions for initialization, adding elements, removing elements, and resizing
Use realloc() to resize the array when needed
Remember to free allocated memory when done
